awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  A Universal Connector for High-Density Microfluidic Chip Interfaces
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is to advance the lab-on-a-chip and other related life science platforms by the introduction of a new standardized microfluidic chip interface. The proposed project advances a novel interface to advance the applications and capabilities of microfluidic chips in both medical and non-medical fields, including dramatically increasing the rate at which doctors and medical researchers can prepare and perform diagnostic tests. The interface enables easy interoperability of devices as the chips can be freely switched out while the result of the hardware remains the same. The success of this project could lead to great breakthroughs in bioenergy, medical diagnostics, and drug therapeutics.

The proposed project undertakes the development of chip interfaces with reduced size and increased channel density by making use of novel interfacing and sealing methods, on a reusable micro-patterned surface. While the technology exists to fabricate microfluidic chips with much smaller dimensions, with more complex on-chip operations, and at a reduced cost, the current limitation is the size of the interfaces bridging the microscopic world of the fluid microchip with the macroscopic world of the laboratory. The work proposed herein could enable chips with 16x the density of sample channels, allowing for vastly more complex diagnostics to be performed and thereby vastly reducing the sample volume needed for accurate diagnostics.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.
org_dir_long_name: Directorate for Technology, Innovation, and Partnerships

por.por_cntn:
This Small Business Innovation Research project addresses the challenge of standardization in the microfluidic field. Specifically, it proposed to design, develop, and manufacture an inexpensive, mass-producible, high-quality connecting interface that fits the majority of the microfluidic chips out in the market. Further, the connector also meets the 1.5-millimeter pitch spacing guideline set forth by the International Organization of Standardization. In addition to being an electrical pin connector, its high number of connections (consisting 1250 channels) to fluid and gas lines makes it highly versatile and adaptable to different uses and applications. 

 

During Phase I of the project, Neptune Fluid Flow Systems succeeded in achieving its objectives in designing, developing, and testing a universal standardized connector as proposed. By using a reliable thread-less method for tubing connections, in combination with a novel sealing method between the connector and tightly packed sample channels and the microfluidic chip, Neptune was able to attain a high density of connections at both the input and output ends of the connector. With its compact size, Neptune’s connector can fit any chip of the size of a microscope slide. The next-step plan is to pursue mass production of this connector design via injection molding and commercialize the product with a viable go-to-market strategy. With a few more years of research and development, this connector will be able to reach the general market and transform the healthcare and life science tools industries, accelerating scientific advances in the lab-on-a-chip and organ-on-a-chip technologies.


Last Modified: 07/07/2024
Modified by: Trevor A Mcqueen
